DOC.HEAD: Aspen Airways Sells Most Routes To Mesa Airlines
Eds: Subs lead to CORRECT ``expect'' to ``except''; Subs 4th graf, `The agreement ...,' to ADD Durango to list of cities.
DOC.TEXT: Aspen Airways Inc. said Tuesday it reached an agreement to sell aircraft and routes except for those serving the ski resort of Aspen to Mesa Airlines Inc. Terms of the deal were not released. Aspen Airways President Don Ringsby said transition is to begin in mid-February and should be completed by June. Mesa Airlines, based in Farmington, N.M., said it will seek an agreement with United Airlines to operate the former Aspen Airways routes as a United Express carrier. The agreement covers Denver-based Aspen Airways' service in Montrose, Colorado Springs, Durango, Gunnison and Grand Junction in Colorado; Sheridan, Casper, Gillette and Jackson, Wyo.; and Farmington. Ringsby said Aspen Airways would continue to serve Denver, Los Angeles, Chicago and Dallas with four British Aerospace 146 jets, which seat 86 passengers each. Mesa said it would offer jobs to all Aspen Airways employees in those cities, and replace 10 Convair 580s Aspen Airways with new aircraft. In addition, Aspen Airways' Denver station will handle all Mesa Airlines' passengers in Denver. Mesa said in a statement the acquisition would add about $40 million to its revenue. Mesa reported revenue of $22.5 million during fiscal year 1989.
